title.narrative: FAMILY AWARENESS OF QUALITY Early Child Development (ECD) AND FAMILY SERVICES

description.narrative: Families are aware of quality Early Child Development (ECD) & Family services, and provide nurturing and responsive care to young children (0-6 years), in targeted districts, which contributes to Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Young children and families, especially the most vulnerable, are utilizing quality Early Child Development (ECD) services

sector.narrative: ECD – Parenting support (including gender responsive parenting) to promote responsive care and early stimulation

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Families are aware of quality ECD & Family services, and provide nurturing and responsive care to young children (0-6 years), intargeted districts

description.narrative: A total of 464,920 families participated in the ECD programme, an increase from 383,159 in 2020. Participation was increased by the implementation of the national parenting curriculum and by heightened community awareness, especially through the national ECD multi-media campaign on social and behaviour change. The families were equipped with skills and knowledge to provide nurturing care to their children and to prevent the spread of COVID-19. A final evaluation of a UNICEF-supported study in 10 districts showed that 57 per cent of children have primary caregivers engaged in childcare compared to 49 per cent in 2015.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2021
